properties.Name: CustomerProductBenefitCriteria
properties.Description:
The one or more benefit criteria that are assigned or linked to a Customer and by which they are identified or qualified from a benefit focus in relationship to a specific Product.

Benefit market segmentation is a strategy for defining consumers by the benefits they seek from a product or service.    

For example, benefits for a product may include price, flavor, health, investment objectives.

The business organization identifies a finite number of Benefit Criteria that are used to identify customers and prospective customers.   These criteria will be unique to each business organization and focus upon that organizations specific information requirements.

The Benefit Criteria is the specific variable or value that may be linked to a Market Segment.

The Benefit Type is the larger category to which the Benefit Criteria belongs.

The following are examples:

Product:  Bond
Benefit Criteria:  Long Term Appreciation
Benefit Type:  Investment Objective

Product:  Stock
Benefit Criteria:  Retirement Savings
Benefit Type:  Investment Objective

Columns.Name: CustomerId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Customer.

Columns.Name: ProductId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Product.

Columns.Name: BenefitCriteriaId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Benefit Criteria.

Columns.Name: PeriodStartDate
Columns.Description: The period start date for which the associated data is effective or 'as-of'.

Columns.Name: PeriodEndDate
Columns.Description: The period end date for which the associated data is effective or 'as-of'.

Columns.Name: CustomerBenefitCriteriaNote
Columns.Description: A note, comment or additional information related to Customer Product Benefit Criteria.

Properties.Description:
The one or more benefit criteria that are assigned or linked to a Customer and by which they are identified or qualified from a benefit focus in relationship to a specific Product.

Benefit market segmentation is a strategy for defining consumers by the benefits they seek from a product or service.    

For example, benefits for a product may include price, flavor, health, investment objectives.

The business organization identifies a finite number of Benefit Criteria that are used to identify customers and prospective customers.   These criteria will be unique to each business organization and focus upon that organizations specific information requirements.

The Benefit Criteria is the specific variable or value that may be linked to a Market Segment.

The Benefit Type is the larger category to which the Benefit Criteria belongs.

The following are examples:

Product:  Bond
Benefit Criteria:  Long Term Appreciation
Benefit Type:  Investment Objective

Product:  Stock
Benefit Criteria:  Retirement Savings
Benefit Type:  Investment Objective
